ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: This course provided me with foundational thinking and writing skills.
Developed and improved on my writing skills, specifically in writing essays about literary works.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: strengths: Professor Campbell is very sweet and the course is really organized.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Yes! You get to read works such as Charlotte's Web which was really nice for me since I think my reading level is pretty low. Professor Campbell is a very nice and accommodating professor as well, so I would take it if you get the chance to. She gives lots of feedback on your writing and meets with you often throughout the semester. Should be noted though that after the initial few weeks of class, the workload did feel like a constant cycle of turning in drafts/papers which became overwhelming at times.

Yes! Take it if you have any interest in literature, as such a wide scope is covered. Professor Campbell honestly wants her students to grow and succeed, and she is a gem of a teacher that every student should experience.

A lot of reading as well as frequent papers. Class discussions often felt forced. The professor also spent a lot of time talking rather than listening.

Feedback was very helpful though and I felt that my writing improved.
